categories.name: Oh, Canada! - Exploring Canadian History and Culture

questions.clue: For 200: This city hosted the 1976 Summer Olympics, marking the first time Canada hosted the event.
For 400: Known as 'The Greatest Canadian,' this social democrat founded Canada's national healthcare system.
For 600: This indigenous group, once known as Eskimos, resides largely in Northern Canada.
For 800: This constitutional act in 1982 gave Canada full control over its constitution.
For 1000: Established in 1912, this organization governs soccer nationwide in Canada and is responsible for its national teams.

categories.name: Soccer World Stars - Legends on the Pitch

questions.clue: This Brazilian legend, often called the greatest of all time, won three FIFA World Cups with Brazil.
This Argentine player, renowned for his product placement, famously swapped shirts with England's Bobby Moore during a memorable game in 1966.
Known for his long tenure at Manchester United, this Englishman won the FIFA World Player of the Year award in 1999 and 2001.
This Canadian soccer player is not only a women’s soccer icon but also held the international goal-scoring record for both men and women.
This French player captained the national team to its first World Cup victory in 1998 and won the Ballon d'Or the same year.

categories.name: Literary Masters - Authors Who Shaped the World

questions.clue: This author of 'Pride and Prejudice' provided keen insights into early 19th-century British society.
Known for 'War and Peace' and 'Anna Karenina', this Russian author explored themes of war, fate, and human emotion.
This English writer, famous for '1984' and 'Animal Farm', critiqued totalitarian regimes.
Born in Canada, this author won a Nobel Prize in Literature and is known for 'The Handmaid's Tale'.
This Colombian author, associated with magical realism, won a Nobel Prize in Literature in 1982 for works like 'One Hundred Years of Solitude'.

categories.name: Marvels of Engineering - Feats of Human Ingenuity

questions.clue: Standing as the tallest freestanding structure in the Western Hemisphere, this Toronto landmark features a revolving restaurant.
This massive 551-foot tall dam, completed in 1936 on the Colorado River, became one of the most famous symbols of American ingenuity.
Revolutionizing the world of international sports, this system was debuted at the 2022 FIFA World Cup to help referees make accurate offside decisions.
Completed in 1973, this suspension bridge in San Francisco is renowned for its iconic orange color and immense length.
Begun in 1882, this still-unfinished cathedral in Barcelona is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and masterpiece of Antoni Gaudí.

categories.name: The Science Behind the Mysteries - Unraveling Phenomena

questions.clue: This phenomenon, often seen as a colorful display in the sky above Canada, is caused by the interaction between solar wind and Earth's magnetic field.
The science behind tides is attributed to the gravitational pull of these two celestial bodies affecting Earth's oceans.
This term describes the bending of light as it passes through different mediums, helping to explain why a straw appears bent in water.
In quantum physics, this type of spooky connection between particles challenges classical concepts of locality and has been experimentally observed.
Theoretically described by Einstein, these ripples in spacetime were directly detected for the first time in 2015 by LIGO, confirming a century-old prediction.

final.clue: This Canadian city, known for hosting major international sports events, was the venue for the opening match of the 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup, a tournament where the home team reached the quarterfinals.
